docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to insure a strong turnout from a crucial voting bloc, President Clinton made a special appeal to women today by highlighting Government efforts to fight breast cancer and telling a rally audience in Virginia that the election ''is not about party, it's about you.'' The President's appearances at the White House and in this Washington suburb today capped a weekend of rallies and organizing by his campaign in 35 states to make sure that women -- the voters whom polls consistently show as central to Mr. Clinton's majority -- turn out to vote.

headline.main: CLINTON CAMPAIGN PUTS AN EMPHASIS ON FEMALE VOTERS

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton makes special appeal to women by highlighting Government efforts to fight breast cancer; appearances at White House and in suburban Virginia caps weekend of rallies and organizing by aides in 35 states to insure that women turn out to vote, as polls consistently show they are central to his majority; he stresses health-care, education and child-based themes that have been central to campaign and have particular resonance with women; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER a career as a child psychiatrist, international consultant and clinical professor of child and adolescent psychiatry at the Yale Child Study Center, Dr. Herbert S. Sacks will become president of the 41,000-member American Psychiatric Association in the spring. Dr. Sacks, who lives in New Haven and practices in Westport, has, among other things, served 10 years as a senior psychiatric consultant to the Peace Corps, helped direct the Yale-AID epidemiological study in the Senegal River Valley in Africa for 12 years and been a consultant on the movies ''Lorenzo's Oil'' and ''Rain Man.''

headline.main: A Psychiatrist Talks About Social Policy
headline.kicker: Connecticut Q&A: Dr. Herbert S. Sacks

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Herbert S Sacks, pres-elect of American Psychiatric Assn; Sacks, Westport, Conn, resident, considers himself strong patient advocate and is interested in relationship of developmental psychological theory and clinical experience to social policy; he comments on impact of managed are on psychiatry, industrialization of American medicine, issue of mental illness coverage as stepchild of managed care, and other issues; photo (M)
docs.snippet: AFTER a career as a child psychiatrist, international consultant and clinical professor of child and adolescent psychiatry at the Yale Child Study Center, Dr. Herbert S. Sacks will become president of the 41,000-member American Psychiatric...

docs.lead_paragraph: Today we endorse the re-election of President Bill Clinton. Readers of this page will know that we share many of the public's concerns about Mr. Clinton's resoluteness and sensitivity to ethical standards in government. But our endorsement is delivered in the unequivocal confidence that he is the best candidate in the field and in the belief that because he has grown in the job he can build on the successes of his first term while correcting its defects. Toward that end, our endorsement comes with a set of recommendations for how Mr. Clinton can, before Election Day, address voters' concerns about his personality and character. First, however, we want to outline the case for Mr. Clinton's re-election based on policy, performance and growth in office. Our view of Mr. Clinton mirrors that of millions of swing voters who are choosing him over Bob Dole and Ross Perot. He is clearly the candidate of hope and progress in this race. No one can doubt his commitment to using government to spur the economy, protect the environment, defend the cities, promote racial justice and combine compassion with fiscal prudence.
docs.abstract: Editorial endorses Pres Clinton for re-election; reviews his positive efforts in areas of the economy, trade, foreign policy, health care and political values; also recommends ways he can address voters' concern about his personality and character
docs.snippet: Today we endorse the re-election of President Bill Clinton. Readers of this page will know that we share many of the public's concerns about Mr. Clinton's resoluteness and sensitivity to ethical standards in government. But our endorsement is...

docs.lead_paragraph: John J. Sweeney used his first anniversary as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to tell business leaders that the labor movement wants to help American businesses compete but will also continue pressuring companies to give workers more money, training and power. Speaking on Friday in New York to a group called Business for Social Responsibility, Mr. Sweeney urged companies to promote both competitiveness and social equity by taking the high road -- by treating workers as assets, by training them and cooperating with them -- instead of taking the low road of squeezing down wages and casting off workers.

headline.main: Union Leader Urges Companies to Forge Alliance With Labor

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO leader John J Sweeney urges business leaders to promote both competitiveness and social equity by treating workers as assets, training them and cooperating with them, rather than squeezing down wages and casting off workers, speech to Business for Social Responsibility (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been 64 years since Kansans elected a Democrat to the United States Senate. But Patricia Bennett, a lifelong Republican, says she is voting for a Democrat, Jill Docking, to fill the last two years of the seat that Bob Dole quit in his quest for the Presidency. The Republican candidate, Representative Sam Brownback, is too conservative for her, Ms. Bennett said, especially on issues like gun control, education and abortion.

headline.main: The Race to Fill Dole's Senate Seat Is Testing the Appeal of Conservatives

docs.abstract: Close race in Kansas between Rep Sam Brownback and Jill Docking to complete Bob Dole's Senate term tests whether conservative Republicans are alienating moderates in own party; Brownback, top lieutenant in Republican revolution in House, is backed by powerful religious-right community, including Christian Coalition; race has overshadowed race between Rep Pat Roberts, Republican, and State Treas Sally Thompson, Democrat, for seat of Repub Sen Nancy Landon Kassebaum (M)
docs.snippet: It has been 64 years since Kansans elected a Democrat to the United States Senate.    But Patricia Bennett, a lifelong Republican, says she is voting for a Democrat, Jill Docking, to fill the last two years of the seat that Bob Dole quit in his quest...

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the economic recovery and substantial numbers of new jobs, the rate of layoffs in the work force in the middle of the decade remained roughly constant compared with the early 1990's, according to revised figures released today by the Labor Department. The figures also showed that the number of people who identified themselves as having lost a job increased in the middle of the decade, providing further statistical underpinning for the anxiety and job insecurity that have become staples of the nation's economic and political discourse.

headline.main: Revised Data Show Layoff Rate Constant in 1990's

docs.abstract: Revised figures released by Labor Dept show that despite economic recovery and substantial number of new jobs, rate of layoffs in middle of decade remained roughly constant compared with early 1990's; figures also show that number of people who identify themselves as having lost a job increased in middle of decade, providing further statistical underpinning for anxiety and job insecurity that have become staples of nation's economic and political discourse; Bob Dole's campaign says revised figures are evidence of why economic anxiety is 'spreading like a virus through America's work force'; Clinton Adm says figures are contradicted by other statistical evidence that suggests layoffs are down at time when unemployment is extremely low; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Despite the economic recovery and substantial numbers of new jobs, the rate of layoffs in the work force in the middle of the decade remained roughly constant compared with the early 1990's, according to revised figures released today by the Labor...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I'm not running to represent a party. I'm running to represent this district,'' said the Congressional candidate, sounding, except for a mild Southern accent, like a Yankee Republican warding off the Gingrich taint. But State Representative Jim Davis, a moderate Democrat and majority leader of the Florida House, was assuring the North Tampa Rotary Club today that he did not seek election to become a tool of Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader.

headline.main: Contest in Tampa Area Reflects G.O.P. Hopes and Anxieties
headline.kicker: POLITICS: FLORIDA -- THE RACE FOR CONGRESS -- Florida's 11th District

docs.abstract: Article on Congressional race in Florida's 11th District; demographic profile; map; moderate Democrat Jim Davis, majority leader of Florida House, is challenged by Republican Mark Sharpe, who has brought in Speaker Newt Gingrich; Tampa-area district has been represented by Sam Gibbons, cantankerous and staunchly liberal, since 1962 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rep. Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, reached out for support from elderly voters today, attending a rally at a senior center here and releasing a new television advertisement attacking his opponent for voting to contain the growth of Medicare. With less than two weeks left in the race, and with polls showing that about half of New Jersey's voters have not decided who they want to fill the seat being vacated by Bill Bradley, Mr. Torricelli is focusing on the third or so of the state's registered voters who are over age 60.

headline.main: Torricelli Focuses on Foe's Medicare Votes

docs.abstract: Repr Robert G Torricelli reaches out for support from elderly voters, attending rally at senior center and releasing new television advertisement attacking his opponent, Repr Richard A Zimmer, for voting to contain growth of Medicare; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study by researchers at the Harvard School of Public Health says that 31 percent of Americans were without health insurance or had difficulty getting or paying for medical care at some time in the last year. The study, reported yesterday in The Journal of the American Medical Association, involved telephone interviews with 3,993 Americans selected at random.

headline.main: Health Costs Pose Problems For Millions, A Study Finds

docs.abstract: New study by researchers at Harvard School of Public Health finds 31 percent of Americans are without health insurance or had difficulty getting or paying for medical care at some time in last year (M)
